tit.e: Gohyaku-Jintengo (Infinite timeframe for Siddhartha Gautama to become Buddha/achieve enlightenment)
Gohyaku-Jintengo (Infinite timeframe for Siddhartha Gautama to become Buddha/achieve enlightenment)
tit.cmt: タイトルであり、次行に説明があるため補足をのぞきました。

sen.j: 五百塵点劫（ごひゃくじんてんごう）とは、法華経如来寿量品で、釈迦の成道の久遠をたとえた語である。
sen.e: Gohyaku-Jintengo (literally, five hundred is like a piece of dust in the infinite time frame) is the word that admires Siddhartha Gautama for spending limitless time in the process of Jodo (completing the path to becoming a Buddha by attaining enlightenment), which is cited in the Nyorai Juryo-bon (the Infinite Life of Buddha Chapter) of Hokekyo (the Lotus Sutra).

Gohyaku-Jintengo (literally, five hundred is like a piece of dust in the infinite time frame) is a word that represents admiration for Siddhartha Gautama spending limitless time in the process of Jodo (completing the path to becoming a Buddha by attaining enlightenment), which is cited in the Nyorai Juryo-bon (the Infinite Life of Buddha Chapter) of Hokekyo (the Lotus Sutra).

Gohyaku-Jintengo (literally, five hundred is like a piece of dust in the infinite time frame) is a word that represents admiration for Siddhartha Gautama spending limitless time in the process of Jodo (completing the path to becoming a Buddha by attaining enlightenment), which is cited in the Nyorai Juryo-bon (the Infinite Life of Buddha Chapter) of Hokekyo (the Lotus Sutra).

sen.cmt: 用語集に合わせました。

sen.j: 「東方五百千万億那由他阿僧祇の国を過ぎて、すなわち一塵を下し、かくの如く、この微塵が尽きんが如き（無くなるまで）、東に行くとしたら、この諸々の世界の数を知ることを得べしや、不（いな）や」と弥勒菩薩に質問している。
sen.e: If a person passes an Eastern (Buddhism-style) galaxy measuring gohyaku-senman-oku nayuta asougi go--in other words, if a person collect one piece of dust--and continues to go eastwards until collecting all the pieces of dust, is he able to know the number of (Buddhism-style) galaxies in the universe or not?"

sen.j: これに対し、寿量品（本門）の「五百千万億那由他阿僧祇」を、五百（億）塵点劫と称して、化城喩品（迹門）の三千塵点劫よりもはるかに長遠であるかが示されるようになった。
sen.e: Meanwhile, the phrase "gohyaku-senman-oku nayuta asougi go" of the Juryo-bon ((one of) 'honmon,' or primordial later 14 chapters of the Lotus Sutra) is called 'Gohyaku(oku)-Jintengo' (literally, fifty billion is like a piece of dust in the infinite timeframe), suggesting (the process of Siddhartha's becoming Buddha is) far more prolonged process than Sanzen-Jintengo in the Kejoyu-bon ((one of) 'shukumon,' or the first 14 chapters of the Lotus Sutra).

sen.j: 法華経における釈迦成道は「われは実に成仏してより已来（このかた）、無量無辺百千万億那由他劫なり」と説いている。
sen.e: In the Lotus Sutra, Siddhartha's enlightenment (Jodo) is described as follows: "It has been muryomuhen hyaku-senman-oku nayuta go (literally, unfathomable, 100*10million*100million*10exponent 60 (or 72), infinite years) since I became Buddha."

sen.j: 経文の記述に素直に従うならば、この五百塵点劫はあくまでもたとえ話として出されただけであって、釈迦が成道した時ではない。
sen.e: If the descriptions in the Lotus Sutra can be taken for granted, the Gohyaku-Jintengo is nothing but a metaphor and is not the time when Siddhartha became Buddha.

sen.j: しかし日蓮は『釈迦御所領御書』などで、「過去五百塵点劫より、このかた、この娑婆世界は釈迦菩薩の御進退の国土なり」などと、五百塵点劫の言葉に開近顕遠の意味を持たせた。
sen.e: Nichiren, however, added the connotation of Kaigon Kennon (Siddhartha is not only a real person who became Buddha but also a true Buddha who has been saving the public since the infinite time of Gohyaku-Jintengo) to Gohyaku-Jintengo, stating in his books such as "Book of the Realm of Siddhartha "that this Shaba (one of galaxies in the Sanzen Daisen Sekai, where our humans live) world has been the realm of Siddhartha Bodhisattva for past Gohyaku-Jintengo years.

sen.e: Incidentally, in general, it is said that Siddhartha was born in India and achieved enlightenment (Jodo) under the Bodhi Tree.

sen.e: The Lotus Sutra, however, confesses that Siddhartha is not an person who was born in India and achieved enlightenment under the Bodhi Tree but a Buddha who had achieved enlightenment (Jodo) in the infinite remote past.
